see.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
see.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: The moment we saw the house, we knew we wanted to buy it.
He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.
Can I see your ticket, please?
I saw the offer advertised in the newspaper.
You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.
can/can’t see
Can you see where the marks are on the wall?
see where/what/who etc
He saw that she was crying.
see (that)
I saw him leave a few minutes ago.
see somebody/something do something
The suspect was seen entering the building.
see somebody/something doing something
As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.
see somebody/something doing something
Have you seen Chris  (=do you know where he is)?
see somebody/something doing something
The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed (=you would not believe it if you did not see it yourself).
see somebody/something doing something
see.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to notice that something is happening or that something is true
see.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: More money must be invested if we are to see an improvement in services.
After a month’s practice, you should see a difference in your playing.
Seeing his distress, Louise put her arm around him.
I would like to see changes in the way the course is run.
‘You’re not denying it, I see, ’ he said coldly.
I can see you’re not very happy with the situation.
see.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to be able to use your eyes to look at things and know what they are
see.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: From the tower, you can see for miles.
I can’t see a thing without my glasses.
His eyes are so bad that he can’t see to read anymore.
see.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to find out information or a fact
see.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: These chocolates are gorgeous. Try some and see for yourself (=find out if it is true).
By looking at this leaflet, you can see at a glance (=find out very easily) how much a loan will cost.
As we have seen in chapter four, women’s pay is generally less than men’s.
From this graph, it can be seen that some people are more susceptible to the disease.
it can be seen that/we can see that
I’ll call him and see how the job interview went.
She went outside to see what was happening.
I’ve just come to see if you want to go out for a drink.
see.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to find out about something in the future
see.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: ‘Can we go to the zoo, Dad?’ ‘We’ll see’ (=used when you do not want to make a decision immediately).
‘How long can you stay?’ ‘I’ll have to see. It depends  (=used when you cannot make a decision immediately).’
We’ll just have to wait and see.
Things will work out, you’ll see (=you will find out that I am right).
I don’t know. We’ll just have to see how it goes on Sunday.
see how it goes/see how things go
It will be interesting to see if he makes it into the team.
I might come – I’ll see how I feel tomorrow.
Let’s try it and see what happens.
see.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: used to tell you where you can find information
see.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: The results are shown in Table 7a (see below).
see.translation[0].definitions[5].note_b: See is always used in the imperative in this meaning
see.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: I see what you mean (=I understand what you are saying).
‘He lives here but works in London during the week.’ ‘Oh, I see (=I understand).’
You see, the thing is, I’m really busy right now  (=used when you are explaining something).
You mix the flour and eggs like this, see (=used to check that someone is listening and understands)?
I can’t see the point of (=I do not understand the reason for) spending so much money on a car.
Do you see the point I’m making  (=do you understand what I’m trying to say)?
The other officers laughed, but Nichols couldn’t see the joke.
I just can’t get her to see reason!
I can’t see why he’s so upset.
see.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to watch a television programme, play, film etc
see.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: Did you see that programme on monkeys last night?
We’re going to see ‘Romeo and Juliet’ tonight.
see.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: to think about or consider someone or something in a particular way, or as having particular qualities
see.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: Having a child makes you see things differently.
Violence is seen in different ways by different people.
As I see it, you don’t have any choice.
as somebody sees it/the way somebody sees it
The way I see it, we have two options.
as somebody sees it/the way somebody sees it
I see the job as a challenge.
He saw himself as a failure.
The peace talks are seen as a sign of hope.
This type of work is often seen as boring.
Teachers need to be seen to be in control.
The government must be seen to be doing something about the rise in violent crime.
see.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: I’ll be seeing her tomorrow night.
I haven’t seen her since we left school.
She’s too sick to see anyone right now.
see.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: I saw Jane while I was out.
see.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: to have an arranged meeting with someone
see.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: Mr Thomas is seeing a client at 2:30.
She was seen by a doctor but didn’t need hospital treatment.
I have to see my teacher about my grades.
see.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: They’ve been seeing a lot of each other.
They’ve seen more of each other since Dan moved to London.
see.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: to imagine that something may happen in the future
see.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: He could see a great future for her in music.
I can’t see him winning, can you?
She’s got a new book coming out, but I can’t see it doing very well.
I just can’t see her as a ballet dancer.
see.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: to make sure or check that something is done
see.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: Don’t worry – I’ll see to it.
The hotel’s owners see to it that their guests are given every luxury.
It’s up to you to see that the job’s done properly.
Please see that the lights are switched off before you leave.
see.translation[0].definitions[15].examp: She was so sick that doctors didn’t think she’d live to see her first birthday.
I never thought I’d live to see the day when women became priests.
She’s seen it all before (=has experienced so much that nothing surprises her) in her long career.
see.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: if a time or place has seen a particular event or situation, it happened or existed in that time or place
see.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: This year has seen a big increase in road accidents.
The city has seen plenty of violence over the years.
see.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: to go somewhere with someone to make sure they are safe
see.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: My mother used to see me across the road.
I’ll get Nick to see you home.
Let me see you to the door (=go with you to the door, to say goodbye).
see.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: to risk the same amount of money as your opponent in a card game
see.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Using the progressive
In meanings 1,2, 3,9, 14, and 18, see is not used in the progressive You say
I am seeing Tina over there
I was suddenly seeing the difference
See is often used with can
I can see Tina over there
I could suddenly see the difference
see.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: to notice something with your eyes, usually without planning to. Also used when saying that you watched a particular programme, film, game etc
Have you seen my keys anywhere?
Did you see the basketball game last night?
look at somebody/something
to keep your eyes pointed toward someone or something, especially someone or something that is not moving
I looked at the map.
She was looking at him in a strange way.
to see something interesting or unusual
I noticed a police car outside their house.
spot
to suddenly see something, especially something you are looking for
Nick spotted the advertisement in the paper.
catch sight of/catch a glimpse of
to suddenly see someone or something for a short time, usually not clearly
I caught sight of him in the hotel lobby, and followed him out the door.
He glimpsed her face as she went into the courtroom.
make out somebody/something
to see something, but only with difficulty
Ahead, I could just make out the figure of a woman.
witness
to see something happen, especially a crime or an accident
The police are asking anyone who witnessed the attack to come forward.
observe
to see and pay attention to something
Officers observed him driving at 100 mph.
sight
to suddenly see something or someone from a long distance, especially when you have been looking for a long time
The missing boys were sighted by a rescue helicopter.
The crew finally sighted land.
Unable to see
blind
unable to see anything
She has been blind from birth.
partially-sighted
not able to see things very well, although not completely blind
Good lighting can be very important for partially sighted people.
visually handicapped/impaired
completely blind or not able to see very much – used especially in official reports, forms etc
a special school for visually impaired children
see.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: an area governed by a bishop
